## Intro Single cell(10x) 

Fluorescent protein of tags are commonly used to label specific cell populations. When these are subjected to single cell sequencing, they can be used to confirm that if specific genes are co-expressed, they aren't a just coming from a doublet or to even calculate doublet rate. 
Instructions for adding custom genes can be found at the [10X genomics] (https://support.10xgenomics.com/single-cell-gene-expression/software/pipelines/latest/advanced/references).
I'll give step by step instruction to do so. 

## Setup
1.Download the reference files from [10X](https://support.10xgenomics.com/single-cell-gene-expression/software/downloads/latest) and unzip into `refdata-cellranger-mm10-3.0.0/`. Make sure to read the build instructions.

2.Make a new folder `reference`. 

3.`cat > temp_genome.fa`. Edit in a text editor. 
I made a new chromosome for each gene, but you can just make one locus. This would require you to create a locus with the appropriate sequence with `NNN` in between them. You may also just consider adding the genes to chromosome 1, where you replace the `NNN` with your sequence. Just make sure to that you track the nucleotide number correctly. I found it eaiser to just have a new chromosome for each sequence. 

You can get specific sequences for many common features from [Addgene](https://www.addgene.org/tools/reference/plasmid-features/).Make sure it is CAPITALIZED. They don't need to be in FASTA format and can just be in a long string. Remeber that the FASTA format give an additional space at the end of each line so your character count may be off if you do it.

5. Append the `GTF` files with `cat refdata-cellranger-mm10-3.0.0/genes/genes.gtf temp_genes.gtf > new_genes.gtf`.

6. Append the `fasta` files with `cat refdata-cellranger-mm10-3.0.0/fasta/genome.fa temp_genome.fa > new_genome.fa`.

7.You can verify this using `tail new_genes.gtf` or `grep -n eGFP new_genes.gtf`.

## Make reference file 

8.This step depends on your environment. Run the `cellranger mkref` using the following configuration. This will create a folder with the new 10xreference genome in the folder `10x_Fl`. 

```
#!/bin/bash -l
#PBS -N NewRef_for_10X
#PBS -l nodes=1:ppn=24,walltime=00:40:00,mem=60gb
#PBS -m abe
#PBS -M verma014@umn.edu

module load umgc
module load cellranger

cd .../reference/
cellranger mkref --genome=10x_Fl --fasta=new_genome.fa --genes=new_genes.gtf --nthreads=24 --memgb=60

```
9.You can verify the your new genes using the step above in the `genome.fa`, `genome.fa.fai` and `genes.gtf`.

## Count 

10.Use `cellranger count` command to map the reads. This is a very memory intensive process so plan ahead. 

```
#!/bin/bash -l
#PBS -l walltime=07:00:00,nodes=1:ppn=24,mem=250gb
#PBS -N Custom_genome_10x_count
#PBS -m abe
#PBS -M verma014@umn.edu

cd $PBS_O_WORKDIR
# Should be run with "qsub -q ram256g" with mesabi. No need to use it for Mangi. Normally takes about 5 hrs.
set -v
ulimit -n
ulimit -n 10000

module load umgc
module load cellranger

cellranger count --id=D0_Fl_genome --fastqs=./fastqfoldername --transcriptome=./10x_Fl --sample=Asakura_Project_016 --expect-cells=3000 --localcore=24 --localmem=200 --chemistry=auto
```
11.You can briefly view the genes with in the Loupe browser in the feature section. 

## Troubleshoot 

12.If you would like to troubleshoot issues with alignment, you can use IGV. Go to `Genomes>Create .genomes File...`. Get the FASTA file from `10x_Fl\fasta\genome.fa` and the `gene file` from `10x_Fl\genes\genes.gtf`. You will have to add a unique identifies and description. 

13.Open up the `BAM` file in IGV with the new genome from the cellranger count output directory in `dir\outs\possorted_genome_bam.bam.

14.Browse for the gene of interst and take a look at the reads that are mapped to each. Since you are using cDNA, there should be basically no spliced reads there.

15. Alternatively you could also look for a specific sequence in the bam file using samtools.
```
'samtools view `file.bam` | grep **YOUR_SEQUENCE** | awk '{print $3 "\t" $4 "\t" $4+length($10)-1}' > sequence.tab'
```
For example, for GFP:
```
'samtools view `file.bam` | grep CAGTCCGCCCTGAGCAAAGACCCCAACGAGAAGCGCGATCACATGGTCCTG
CTGGAGTTCGTGACCGCCGCCGGGATCACTCTCGGCATGGACGAGCTG | awk '{print $3 "\t" $4 "\t" $4+length($10)-1}' > GFPsequence.tab'
```
## Verify reads
The BAM files that comes out from the cellranger count includes all aliged reads including low quality reads and reads that are mapped to multiple genes. These are not used for UMI counts. The requirements are listed (here)[https://kb.10xgenomics.com/hc/en-us/articles/115003710383-Which-reads-are-considered-for-UMI-counting-by-Cell-Ranger-]

```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
library(DropletUtils)
```
```{r}
mol.info.file <- "D:/Informatics/MVSingleCell/D3GTWC9/molecule_info.h5"
molinfo <- read10xMolInfo(mol.info.file)
```

You can pull out the reads that were counted for UMI counts from this file.
You will used SAM tools to extract those reads. Information for using 'samtools' for this can be found (here)[https://kb.10xgenomics.com/hc/en-us/articles/360007068611-How-do-I-get-the-read-counts-for-each-barcode-].
The instruction for getting the BAM file for specific barcodes can be found (here)[https://kb.10xgenomics.com/hc/en-us/articles/360022448251-Is-there-way-to-filter-the-BAM-file-produced-by-10x-pipelines-with-a-list-of-barcodes-]


```{r}

```
This will take as much time as it takes to read the whole sam file so be patient. 
```
module load samtools
samtools view file.bam | grep "MM:i:1" | cat header.sam - | samtools view -Sb - > UMIreads.bam
samtools sort UMIreads.bam -o UMIreads.sorted.bam
samtools index UMIreads.sorted.bam
```
Examine mapped reads using IGV: 
Open these up in IGV to find which reads were used for UMI counting. 
Alternatively, you can just group and color the MM tag in IGV. 

## Sanity check 
One of the things that surpised me is how well the alignment actually works.For example, this is the alighment between GFP and TdTomato. While the small sequences have good alignment, you still get ~90 bp reads with the 10x data after barcodes. In my spot checking, I could not find any reads that I could say were definate misalignments. This makes sense as reads that are mapped to multiple genes are thrown out and not accounted in the UMI count. This gives me confidence that the reads are not simply misread. 
In addition, having the WPRE segment in the TdTomatoWPRE is helpful. Since 10x is 3' biased, most of the reads are on the WPRE and not the tdTomato. I am hesitent to map just the WPRE and not the whole tdTomatoWPRE because I suspect with out it, there might be some reads that would be between tdTomato and GFP, they will no longer get thrown out.
